comments.commentBody: So much for the infallibility of the Pope in matters of faith and morals! The Catholic Church dictates public policy regarding a woman's most personal and private decisions, while the Pope (and the Church hierarchy)  advocates life for the "unborn" while allowing the "already born" young children to be put in harms way, and  unprotected from pedophile priests.   Shame on the Pope, and shame on the Catholic Church.

It seems that the Church viewed this as a theological issue, not a criminal issue. Repentance and absolution are a key elements of the Church's theological marketing strategy - a way to offer potential converts a road into the Church though admission of sin and absolution by clergy in order to begin anew. What would happen to this symbolic ability of the Church to commute sin by absolution as mediator between the parishioner and the judgment of the Almighty if the Church said, "Repentance and absolution work in all things EXCEPT this one." Absolution's power lies in its unbiased totality. But in the attempt to keep this theology unmitigated by exception, the Church seems to have forgotten that absolution does not excuse the crime. It only deals with the soul.

Of course, they were probably also pretty worried about getting sued again and again and again.

Ironically, by involving a standing Pope and embarrassing him through a undeniable demonstration of his complicity, the Church may finally deal with this issue in a permanently constructive fashion.
When he resigns, who will be the next pope?

"The Vatican has said that the abuse dated back decades and that Father Murphy’s age and ill health were reason enough not to dismiss him from the clergy." ?????

Since when have ANYONE'S 'ill health' and age been more important than hundreds of sexually abused children.

I say it is high time that the Pope resigns....he has lost all credibility at this point.

I've read it all and I'm leaving the church.   I can't in good faith continue to bring my kid to a church where the leadership is doing nothing meaningful to avoid recruiting predators and, when those predators get caught, the leadership does nothing meaningful to stop them.     Talk about Pharisees    I have a responsibility to my child to provide the safest possible environment for his religious development.     I'm going to exercise that by going to the ECLA from this point on.   I've abandoned this church, but certainly not the faith that comes to us through the ages.   The Catholic church will not change in any meaningful way.   The bishops will continue to say that celibacy rules are not the problem.      In fact, they aren't just not progressive --- they are regressive.      Look at what they are doing to the Roman Missal as one example.   Can you see Christ coming back and thinking "Yea right --- this is exactly what I had in mind?"   Not likely.
crossroads is an interesting way of putting it

This Vatican has been particularly incompetent and tone deaf to the modern world. Clearly, from the experience of clergy pedophilia in the US, the number one priority of the church was to protect the institution. That's world wide and should come as no surprise. Imagine excommunicating the mother and doctor of a 9 year old rape victim carrying twins, in Brazil, for aborting the fetuses that might kill the child. These men have no clue, as we should expect from men of all fundamentalist religions trying to bring us back to the middle ages. Yet, as that great philosopher, Latka Gravas, observed: Where would we be without mindless superstition and meaningless ritual? It's what separates us from the lower beasts.

What am I missing here?  Ratzinger(not worthy of the title Pope) instructs bishops they will be excommunicated if they reveal pedophile investigations, i.e. tell the truth.  Yet he goes to extremes to protect and prevent the punishment of molesting priest after molesting priest.  Nothing short of his resignation along with all the church officials involved in the coverup will suffice.  Only then can the the victims begin to have some sense of justice and closure.

The Catholic church captures today's salacious headlines because the preponderance of sexual abuse is occurring in Catholic churches. not an embedded (no pun intended) problem, say, as in the Episcopalian or Congregational churches. Yet the Church hierarchy circles the wagons, lashing out at any who would dare cross them or their public policy stands. Ask Patrick Kennedy. As hypocrites, they attack the perceived crimes i=of others while doing their mightiest to deflect their own criminal shortcomings

I must warn you all that there is a subtle plan afoot to destroy the Catholic Church. The conspirators will strike from within. The first stage is to get a very conservative, 80 year old man with limited experience of actual 21st century life appointed as Pope. Ideally, this Pope should adhere rigidly to matters of church doctrine that are highly destructive to the Church, such as repeatedly insisting on celibacy for priests, a very secondary role for women in the Church, rejection of homosexuals, the banning of any form of birth control and the concealment of pedophile priests. If this were all, however, the Church might still somehow survive intact, although in a weakened form.

The master stroke is to persuade the cardinals to appoint someone who has been in charge for years of the central Vatican office for dealing with matters relating to pedophile priests. We know that thousands of such cases have been referred to the Vatican, and that the Vatican has been stonewalling such cases for years. Thus it would only be a matter of time before it was found that the new Pope had been involved in concealing or ignoring many such cases. Since the cases of pedophilia are still coming to light in their hundreds, and the Catholic faithful are disgusted by these crimes and the lack of action of their bishops and the Vatican (which guided their actions), then the new Pope would be widely discredited, and the Catholic Church terribly damaged. There are those who might say that the Church is much to wise to expose itself to these dangers. One can only hope that morality, and not self-interest and arrogance, will guide the actions of the Church to prevent this evil plan from succeeding.
Time to make history, this pope needs to be removed. He had knowledge of abuses in Germany and did nothing. The rock needs a scrubbing.

This is just another incident recording the decline of the Catholic Church as an institution. Abuse of people, other than children, by the male hierarchy is historic.
I was raised a Catholic so these incidences of deceit and arrogance are not new. The difference is that they are now making the public press and are occuring in the new age of information.

For that reason I separated the man run institution from the faith many years ago.

Easy to do because the institution and its men have yet to practice most of Christ's basic precepts. They are in fact a political organization. For example, concerned about abortion but silent on Americans (who were not aborted) being sent to foreign countries to kill innocent civilians.

In addition, the pomp and circumstance events with gilded draped robes is the antithesis of Christ's sack cloth and sandals. The rich businessmen and attorneys whom Christ admonished are usually the closest friends of the Cardinals and Bishops.
What the Catholic Church as an institution is forgetting is that this is no longer the middle or industrial age. Their despotic controls in cooperation with the powerful elite is no longer available to them as the age of information exposes the previously behind-the-scene manipulation of society.

As a Catholic I was extremely disturbed that they did not choose a Cardinal from a third world country -- an African or Hispanic. Choosing an old white German told me that they had just sealed their fate and moved the institution onto a slippery slope in the new world.

They are however diligently watching the activities of American nuns as those nuns work in society for social justice. The Church is investigating the nuns and their orders deciding whether or not to corral them back into convents. Of course, the nuns’ social work with the poor is an embarrassment to the arrogant hierarchy and their luxurious life style.

New York Times ought to investigate that story.
If there really is a God, this Pope will be forced to abdicate.

We must not let this vile, abetted crime against humanity pass without some form of secular punishment. The vatican's sole line of defense (viz; the media and an anti-catholic bias are exaggerating a bygone evil) borders on the ludicrous. Benedict's venality requires immediate prosecution, with the venue being the world court at The Hague.(How many others suffered after Benedict's generous reassignment of the beast)?
There is no reason to believe one word that comes out of the Pope's mouth.

A recent DOJ study of child abusers in the general US population indicated approximately 70% of the cases involved the abuse of young girls. However, the Catholic church seems to seek and nurture a different phenotype who prefer to abuse altar boys over young girls by about a 70% to 30% ratio. This indicates an absolute institutional selection of these pedophiles. This would not continue without the enablement or support of very senior leaders of the Catholic church including the Pope. His recent letter to the Irish indicates he believes the saving of one fallen prelate is somehow more significant the the losses of all of the victims. A really harsh punishment imposed on a priest is taking away the honor of performing mass?????

Even more curious is the suggestion the allowing priest to marry would 'solve' the problem. If priests are allowed to marry, God help the members of the choir.
Par for the course, the Catholic Church and the Pope. How wearing a pointy hat and unusual designer clothes gives one truth and wisdom to impart to the world and their followers is beyond me.

I know Catholics who feel as though their church is overly scrutinized and criticized. They wish more attention would be paid to the good work that Catholics do. But when, exactly, can we expect the leaders of the church to give a full, honest and credible accounting of the history of abuse in the church? And, more importantly, when can we expect the leaders of the church to stop coddling men who rape children?

In this most recent case, from Wisconsin, the offending priest asked that he not be defrocked because he was old and wished to die with dignity.

In other words, he asked for mercy because he was at a vulnerable stage in his life, right?

Just like the children he molested.

I know I'm stating the obvious, but it is extremely creepy that the Pope and his underlings are more concerned with preserving the power and status of the church than with ridding their ranks of rapists.

Very creepy indeed.

I was raised Catholic and was a church organist at a large church in TX. Asst priest from there now doing 3 life terms for abuse. I only read about this later and was shocked that the priests in the house saw nothing. Why doesn't the Pope consider assaulting children a legal matter? If left to the church and a minor is assaulted does the pope ever think about the law? Are they still above the law in every country?
